description: From Middle English erect, a borrowing from Latin ērectus (“upright”), past participle of ērigō (“raise, set up”), from ē- (“out”) + regō (“to direct, keep straight, guide”).

adjectives.description: erect (comparative more erect, superlative most erect)

entries.meaning: Upright; vertical or reaching broadly upwards.
(of body parts) Rigid, firm; standing out perpendicularly, especially as the result of stimulation.
examples: The penis should be fully erect before commencing copulation.

entries.meaning: (of a person) Having an erect penis.
examples: OK, baby, I'm erect now. Let's get it on!

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Bold; confident; free from depression; undismayed.
(heraldry) Elevated, as the tips of wings, heads of serpents, etc.

description: From Middle English erecten, from the adjective (see above).

verbs.description: erect (third-person singular simple present erects, present participle erecting, simple past and past participle erected)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To put up by the fitting together of materials or parts.
examples: to erect a house or a fort

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to stand up or out.

definitionGroups.group: To raise and place in an upright or perpendicular position; to set upright; to raise.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, aviation, of a gyroscopic attitude indicator) To spin up and align to vertical.
examples: As soon as electrical power was restored, the attitude indicators' gyros would have begun to erect.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To lift up; to elevate; to exalt; to magnify.
examples: I, who am a party, am not to erect myself into a judge.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To animate; to encourage; to cheer.
(transitive, astrology) To cast or draw up (a figure of the heavens, horoscope etc.).
examples: In 1581 Parliament made it a statutory felony to erect figures, cast nativities, or calculate by prophecy how long the Queen would live or who would succeed her.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To enter a state of physiological erection.
(transitive) To set up as an assertion or consequence from premises, etc.
examples: from fallacious foundations, and misapprehended mediums, erecting conclusions no way inferrible from their premises

entries.meaning: (transitive) To set up or establish; to found; to form; to institute.
